message:
Are you with or against GitFlow? Why?
Based on what do you decide to use GitFlow for a project?
------------------------------------------------
So, i have been reading about gitflow long ago but never really had the chance to use it as the workflow for a project from the beginning, but i have that chance now so i decided to use it but then started reading about opinions against gitflow as well, and i kinda feel lost in between so i thought i should listen to your experiences and opinions! :)
story: Mahmoud Tantawy created a poll in Egyptian Geeks.

data.message:
Simple explanation for GitFlow WorkFlow: http://jeffkreeftmeijer.com/2010/why-arent-you-using-git-flow/

Arguments against it: http://endoflineblog.com/gitflow-considered-harmful
and the follow-up: http://endoflineblog.com/follow-up-to-gitflow-considered-harmful

I've read these articles and the comments as well but couldn't make up my mind, also searched the group here for similar discussions but found none.
With for the sake of trying something new

I'm against using anything as is. You should adapt to whatever makes you and your team comfortable and productive. Just like "agile" and people saying you're doing agile wrong or agile is better. Screw it. If you're happy with svn and it fits the bill, go for it.  When it comes to gitflow, I don't see it as a good starting point, but take a look at it, and take the parts that would make your life better.
It gives a very logical, standardized yet easy way to manage a repo. So why not?

Well, I too have read the argument against it, when we were making the shift to gitflow, and I found it to be bullshit. 

Except for the history readability part, which is partially solved by tags in Gitflow, the other points seem to be emotional more than logical, and the dude seems to be disgruntled, nothing more.

We are having a little problem with GitFlow, but we have had the same exact problem with almost every other flow we had before, and it is highly related to our codebase.

I agree with Hassan Ibraheem in general, but in this case I am very much for GitFlow.

A few of the things i really love about GitFlow:

1. When you use the "git flow" command, it is way harder to make mistakes, and take a branch from the wrong place, or merge a branch to the wrong branch, or rebase on an outdated branch. This takes away a lot of human errors.

2. I like rebasing on top of develop branch, it keeps conflicts contained in feature branches, and leaves the develop branch intact till the developer deliberately decides to merge back into develop. Every developer will fix the conflicts on their feature branch, and only they will suffer from broken code, not the whole team.

3. I like the concept of "release" branches, very much.
Bottom line, it is not heaven, but it is really good.

Also, it is better for teams than for individuals. Individuals don't really need all that overhead. 

That being said, I personally use it for my own individual projects anyway. :)
